item.title: By: David Forck (thirster42)
item.dc:creator: David Forck (thirster42)
item.content:encoded:
Seems like the makings of another awesome tool by redgate. here’s my first impressions:

The very first thing that I noticed was that it wouldn‚Äôt let me run it as administrator. This is important to me because I have two separate accounts where I work, my every day privileges account and my elevated admin account. My admin account is what I use to connect to sql server so now I have to switch users to run this.

Definitely don‚Äôt like it defaulting to having all indexes selected to fix.

Clicking on the Fix column heading trying to either select all of them or sort broke the application for me üòÄ

Clicking the other column headings do nothing.

Hitting ctrl-a will select everything, but clicking on a ‚ÄúFix‚Äù button only deselects or selects that specific one. Options to select or deselect all would be nice.

Clicking Fix Indexes pop up a window, allowing you to let Redgate fix the index or to generate the script and let you run it. Awesome!

The results don‚Äôt keep the list of indexes after closing and reopening the application. It would be nice if it kept the server, database, index name, and when it was fixed so that DBAs could determine how often they‚Äôre fixing an index (so they can either schedule the fix or reevaluate the need for the index).

Fixing an index doesn‚Äôt take it off the index analysis list.

Another nice to have is if it picked up the maintenance plans/jobs that reorg/build indexes.
